channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Immigration pause. Pete Hegseth. Special election. Kids’ vaccines. Cold records. Lonely Americans. Blocking the sun. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Republican wins Tennessee special election in Trump country, as Democrats gain ground
item.description: GOP nominee Matt Van Epps defeated Democrat Aftyn Behn in Tennessee’s ruby-red 7th Congressional District, the Associated Press projected. The contest, which became more competitive than initially expected, was the latest test of voter attitudes about President Donald Trump’s agenda and Democrats’ response.

item.title: Holocaust museum gets the pen that was used to save dozens of children at Auschwitz
item.description: Erno Spiegel’s fountain pen was a subtle weapon in the fight for survival in a Nazi concentration camp.

item.title: Trump rails against Somali migrants: ‘I don’t want them in our country’
item.description: President Donald Trump ended a Cabinet meeting Tuesday with a rant against Somali migrants, accusing them of having “ripped off” Minnesota and using dehumanizing language to attack a group he has increasingly targeted in recent weeks. The president’s comments came amid reports that his administration is ramping up immigration enforcement efforts targeting undocumented Somali immigrants in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area.

item.title: This moral slum of an administration is sickening, George F. Will writes
item.description: Regarding Venezuela, Ukraine and much more, Trump and his acolytes are worse than simply incompetent.

item.title: National Guard shooting suspect charged with murder, assault offenses
item.description: U.S. Attorney Jeanine Pirro has said the suspect, Rahmanullah Lakanwal, will face additional charges as the investigation continues.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Parents at odds over ‘wicked smart’ teen who’s behind in four APs
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Parents at odds over ‘wicked smart’ teen who’s behind in four APs

item.title: A D.C. wedding in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points

item.title: RFK Jr.’s vaccine advisers plan biggest change yet to childhood schedule
item.description: The new chair of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices says the panel is preparing this week to vote to end universal hepatitis B vaccination at birth and to examine whether childhood shots are triggering allergies and autoimmune disorders. Public health groups accuse the group of spreading misinformation.

item.title: Former president of Honduras freed from U.S. prison after Trump pardon
item.description: Juan Orlando Hernández had been sentenced last year to 45 years in prison after being convicted in a U.S. court of running a “narco-state” that helped send South American cocaine to the United States.

item.title: Pete Hegseth. Alina Habba. D.C. shooting suspect. ‘Everywhere chemicals.’ TSA fee. Buy now, pay later. Olivia Nuzzi. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Hegseth tries to distance himself from boat strike fallout as White House emphasizes admiral’s role
item.description: The Washington Post reported exclusively Friday that Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth gave a spoken order to kill the entire crew of a vessel thought to be ferrying narcotics in the Caribbean Sea. When two survivors were detected, the military commander overseeing the operation, Adm. Frank M. Bradley, directed another strike to comply with Hegseth’s order that no one be left alive, people with direct knowledge of the matter told The Post.

item.title: The White House revealed its pared-back Christmas display — with a Trump LEGO portrait and ‘Be Best’ baubles
item.description: In her first holiday back in charge of White House decor, first lady Melania Trump presented a straightforward, even understated — at least by White House standards — look. The tour route differs from years past because the traditional entrance has been leveled to build President Donald Trump’s 90,000-square-foot ballroom.

item.title: TSA will begin charging a $45 fee for travelers without a Real ID or passport starting Feb. 1
item.description: Monday’s announcement urges travelers to pay the $45 fee online before they travel. The Transportation Security Administration is working with partners to offer pay-in-advance options, the news release says.

item.title: The alleged National Guard shooter once served in an elite CIA-backed unit. But his life unraveled as a refugee in the U.S.
item.description: The course of Rahmanullah Lakanwal’s journey from a trusted U.S. battlefield ally to the suspected shooter of two National Guard members on the streets of downtown D.C. remains unclear, in part. But like many Afghans who had worked for the United States and came to this country after the chaotic August 2021 U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan, he appeared to struggle to adapt to his new circumstances.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Gay parents of biracial child ‘overthink’ a private school option
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Gay parents of biracial child ‘overthink’ a private school option

item.title: Trump unlawfully appointed his former attorney Alina Habba to serve as top prosecutor in New Jersey, appeals court rules
item.description: The decision could have far-reaching implications for other controversial Trump appointments that have been challenged in court.

item.title: A top aide resigns in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Ozempic is changing how we spend money and time, plus what we eat
item.description: As people’s bodies change through the use of GLP-1s, so does their spending across industries including fashion, restaurants, gyms and travel.

item.title: Pete Hegseth. ICE raids. California shooting. Deadly floods. Vaccine approvals. Ozempic habits. Hungry microbes. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Lane Kiffin will take over as LSU's football coach following days of drama
item.description: He became a hovering theme of the latter part of the college football season as his future at Mississippi became uncertain.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: Under Pete Hegseth, the Defense Department has been pulled into Trump’s efforts to punish political foes
item.description: In threatening to deploy the military justice system against Democrats, the secretary of defense has joined President Donald Trump’s norm-shattering bid to punish adversaries.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: House panel joins Senate in launching bipartisan inquiry of Pentagon over Hegseth's order to kill boat strike survivors
item.description: The Senate and House armed services committees’ pledge followed a Washington Post report revealing that Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth ordered that a U.S. strike leave no survivors.

item.title: Playwright Tom Stoppard dies at 88. His works were among the most acclaimed and oft-performed of the past half-century.
item.description: Stoppard, a Czech-born British dramatist, explored political, artistic and scientific questions — often with mash-ups of high and low culture. His most popular works include Tony Award-winning plays “Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead,” “Travesties” and “The Real Thing.”

item.title: Ask Sahaj: I’m scared to tell my parents I didn’t dump my boyfriend
item.description: Ask Sahaj: I’m scared to tell my parents I didn’t dump my boyfriend

item.title: An investor called $140,000 the new poverty line. Experts disagreed but said he had a point.
item.description: Michael Green’s tally of the costs of raising a family in the United States today is going viral, even if some economists scoff at his math.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: FDA will impose strict vaccine requirements, claiming covid shot contributed to children’s deaths
item.description: Vinay Prasad, the nation’s top vaccine regulator, told Food and Drug Administration officials that the agency will rethink its framework for annual flu shots, examine whether Americans should be receiving multiple vaccines at the same time and require vaccine makers to show far more data to prove the safety and value of their products.

item.title: Counter-terrorism officials vetted D.C. National Guard shooting suspect before he entered U.S.
item.description: Rahmanullah Lakanwal, 29, arrived in the United States through Operation Allies Welcome, a Biden-era program that helped resettle Afghan nationals after the U.S. military withdrawal from Afghanistan in 2021.

item.title: 50 years ago, he saw a document in the JFK file. Where is it now?
item.description: Despite Trump’s orders, report that Mexico believed Cuba was behind the assassination has not emerged.

item.title: D.C. police to begin patrolling with National Guard after fatal attack
item.description: Troops patrolling in D.C. will be paired with local law enforcement personnel, at least temporarily, in the wake of the Wednesday attack that killed one National Guard member and critically injured another, according to an email obtained by The Washington Post and two D.C. police officials. If enacted on a long-term basis, the change would significantly shift the way National Guard members have worked with law enforcement in the District since their arrival.

item.title: Hegseth gave a verbal order to kill everybody in first Caribbean boat strike, officials say
item.description: As two men clung to a stricken, burning ship targeted by SEAL Team 6, the Joint Special Operations commander followed the defense secretary’s order to leave no survivors.

item.title: Zelensky’s top aide, lead negotiator resigns amid corruption probe
item.description: Andriy Yermak, the head of Ukraine’s presidential office, had emerged as one of the most contentious and powerful figures in the country.

item.title: And they’re off! Here are 6 names to watch in the race to the midterms.
item.description: Columnists pick the top candidates to watch as the 2026 midterms begin.

item.title: 10 questions, and don't forget the bonus wager! Finish off your week with On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: 46 gifts we’re giving (and wishing for) this year
item.description: We asked Washington Post staff members what items they really wanted this year, and what they deemed worthy to gift — the tech that improved their lives, the decanter beautiful enough to display, the game to make their family laugh together, the silk pillowcase their wife loves.

item.title: D.C. shooting. Hong Kong fire. No-cash bail. Mar-a-Lago. Black Friday. Creative hobbies. Vanished civilization. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: One of the National Guard members shot near the White House on Wednesday has died, Trump says
item.description: The victim, Spec. Sarah Beckstrom, was a 20-year-old from West Virginia. The second critically wounded National Guard member, 24-year-old Staff Sgt. Andrew Wolfe, is still fighting for his life, President Donald Trump said.

item.title: 4 charts show who’s feeling good about the economy — and who isn’t
item.description: In surveys, many people report feeling exasperated by high prices and slowing incomes. But not everyone is equally upset. And some are even feeling better about their finances now than they were a few months ago.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: A fiancé famous for waiting hurries up when sibling sets a date
item.description: Carolyn Hax: A fiancé famous for waiting hurries up when sibling sets a date

item.title: The location of historic Native American villages mentioned by John Smith was unknown — until now
item.description: In the 1600s, English explorer Smith wrote of how he and his men were attacked by Native Americans along the Rappahannock River in Virginia. This summer, archaeologists came upon physical proof of the towns and villages that he had described.

item.title: How Thanksgiving shrank down to the size of a screen
item.description: The incredible shrinking all-American holiday

item.title: National Guard shooting suspect drove to D.C. from Washington state and faces charges of assault with intent to kill, Pirro says
item.description: The two members of West Virginia’s National Guard who were shot and critically wounded have been identified as Sarah Beckstrom, 20, and Andrew Wolfe, 24, U.S. Attorney Jeanine Pirro said at a news conference. Officials described the shooting as a targeted attack, but no potential motive has been established.

item.title: Happy Thanksgiving from On The Record!
item.description: Answer now to earn your holiday points.

item.title: D.C. shooting. Hong Kong fire. Trump case. Economic exasperation. Ozempic 2.0. Happiness recipe. Green Wednesday. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: An Afghan national has been identified as the man in custody in the shooting of National Guard members, two people familiar say
item.description: The suspect, Rahmanullah Lakanwal, arrived in the U.S. in 2001 and for a time lived in Washington state.

item.title: Guardsmen shot in D.C. were targeted by attacker and are in critical condition, officials said in updates. Follow our coverage.
item.description: West Virginia Gov. Patrick Morrisey initially said both Guard members were killed, but he later said he was getting “conflicting reports” about their condition. The suspect, who was also wounded, was taken into custody and transported to a hospital, officials said.

item.title: Two West Virginia National Guard members who were shot in D.C. have died, officials say. Police have a suspected shooter in custody.
item.description: “These brave West Virginians lost their lives in the service of their country,” wrote West Virginia Gov. Patrick Morrisey. “We are in ongoing contact with federal officials as the investigation continues.”
